doc.title: Issues for debate post 2Q25
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/ZIM Issues for debate post 2Q25ZIM Issues for debate post 2Q25_2025-08-28

passages.text: Key questions: 2H demand outlook and trade uncertainty, Capacity and cost flex in FY25/FY26, Red Sea re-opening, USTR headwinds, ZIM spot vs contract, Unit cost savings from new fleet, Industry capacity management (speed, idling, scrapping), quarterly divis, FCF & Capital allocation.
What's the debate? In this report, we summarise key issues for investors to discuss with ZIM management following its 2Q25 results on 20 Aug 2025.

Top of the agenda: ZIM subject to higher idiosyncratic risk, on top of a weak 2H macro. Zim's 2Q rates and volume dynamics were relatively poorer vs. Hapag- Lloyd and Maersk due to its higher TP exposure. ZIM's rates were down \(17\%\) QoQ vs Maersk/HLAG down \(7\% /11\%\) . In 2Q25, Volumes were down by \(6\%\) yoy, vs. BarcE \(+2\%\) (1Q25 \(+12\%\) , Maersk and Hapag- Lloyd 2Q volumes \(+4\%\) and \(+12\%\) yoy, respectively). Looking into 2H, we see the biggest risks to volumes coming from weaker US demand due to front- loading from US shippers in 1H and potentially a weaker US consumer impacted by inflationary pressures. ZIM is the most at risk with regard to this US 2H risk. In addition, ZIM will also face more challenging comps from 2H24. Management commented that ZIM benefited from very strong volume growth in 2H24, beating records in 3Q and 4Q from a carried quantity perspective.

View and valuation: We rate the stock Underweight with a \(13.3\) PT, as we continue to see earnings normalization risk ahead as mid- term structural challenges remain, in our view. As a pure- play container shipping line, ZIM remains highly operationally geared to the spot market and also has a material exposure to the transpacific trade lane, which has been very volatile in FY25 thus far. A lot of unclarity remains on the demand environment in the 2H, subject to tariffs and macro risk. We expect a Red Sea reopening earliest in FY26 and we model for a more challenging FY26 backdrop reflecting an assumed FY impact from Red Sea reopening, whilst we note a difficult demand/supply imbalance in 2027 with \(+7\%\) new built capacity addition planned.
For our post results report on ZIM, please see ZIM/HLAG: 2H and 2026 still risky - UW, published today.

Current trading heavily impacted by TP. 2Q25 results missed consensus due to weaker rates and volumes on the TP where ZIM has \(40\%\) exposure. Management stated during the conference call that the surge in TP demand in May was short- lived and current demand on trade remains

relatively weak. Has there been any uplift in China to US bookings post the recent 90- day extension? Has all China- US capacity been re- instated now? With 1Q and April volumes into the US stronger than history according to Sea Intelligence, how high are inventories? Which RoW countries have been the strongest post "Liberation Day"? How much more production capacity is there in RoW? 2Q did not fully benefit from the stronger rates towards the end of the quarter due to the revenue recognition delay between \(\%\) of completion vs spot rate at departure. What was the impact of revenue recognition on 2Q earnings given weaker dynamics from March? How large will the 3Q tailwind vs spot rates evolution at departure be? How easily can ZIM refocus capacity on other growth trade lanes?

FY25 outlook - cautious on 2H: Management lifted the lower end of the FY25 EBITDA and EBIT guidance, to reflect a solid 1H, but a cautious view on 4Q/2H. Management now expects volumes to be flat YoY in FY25, down from LSD at 1Q, with the new guidance reflecting a steep slowdown in 2H with 1H already reflecting \(

proposal. Given ZIM's material exposure to the Transpacific (c. \(40\%\) of volumes), how easy is it to re- shuffle vessels to minimize costs? What is ZIM's exposure to the US- China trade lane? Management have previously flagged that it will need to find a way to recover these fees, but did not specify how it will be done. Could management elaborate on the various methods it could use to limit exposure to this policy? How could this policy impact the container shipping industry? What are the next steps for this policy?

Inquiry Oversupply dynamic and how long until structural repair emerges? At 2Q25, management noted that market fundamentals still point to supply growth outpacing demand going forward; however, RS and Port disruptions are causing a temporary effective shortage of supply. Has management's view on environmental- led scrapping changed following the IMO proposed mid- term measure announcements in April? Is there global capacity for scrapping and what is the lead time for scrapping? How does the newly adopted Hong Kong convention impact the overall capacity? How much capacity can slow steaming absorb in FY25? How slow can vessels sail? How long will it take within the industry for structural repair to emerge? What would be the first signs? Increase in blank sailings or scrapping? How much capacity can be absorbed by low- speed sailing? Are scrapping and slow steaming enough to support freight rates even if demand does not pick up? If, on the other hand, demand picks up, and global trade activity regains its relationship with global GDP growth, can that pick- up be enough to avoid oversupply risks? Won't all players just chase these volumes and put further pressure on rates?

Unit cost control. Management stated that any vessel renewals in FY25/26 will benefit from lower rates vs. those secured in FY21/22, which should reduce overall debt going forward. When should we expect to see the full benefit of the fleet renewal programme to unit costs? Can management provide any colour on the charter cost outlook expected as the fleet is renewed? During the 2Q conference call, management stated that the overall cost structure of the industry and of ZIM has gone up when compared to pre- Covid levels, incl. wages, charter costs, bunker costs, etc. What are the incremental opportunities to reduce unit costs from here? What level of asset utilisation is needed to continue improving unit costs sequentially? How should the market expect the non- bunker unit fuel costs to evolve? Have the Red Sea diversions meaningfully impacted short- term unit costs? How embedded are these new costs and how quickly would cost normalize with the Suez Canal resume? What are the main sources of costs that will normalize?

Contract vs. spot rates. Post 2025 contract negotiations, management said that its Transpacific contract share will be \(30\%\) , similar to last year, with contracts starting from May 1st. According to the CFO, rates have been agreed at a higher rate year on year. How did management approach the contract negotiations? Has the strategy/approach changed given tariff/trade uncertainty? If all customers were willing to meet the minimum required contract rates, what would be the optimal share of contract/spot for ZIM on the transpacific? Does management expect issues in increasing exposure in contract rates once spot rates turn given the recent strategic increase towards spot rate volumes?

Capital allocation. At 2Q ZIM has proposed a dividend of \(0.06\) vs BBG consensus at \(0.34 -\) reflecting a \(30\%\) payout ratio at the low end of the \(30 - 50\%\) policy. What were the moving parts which drove a lower than expected net income vs. consensus? What are the financial leverage metrics that management focuses on? Are there covenants on debt? What level of financial leverage is a comfortable level? What is the minimum level of liquidity? How will ZIM manage its capex commitments in a downcycle with significant cash- flow burn? Are there any assets that can be monetised should liquidity concerns emerge? As the majority of the debt are capitalised leases (vessel charters), is financial leverage a concern to ZIM's charterers? How much cash capex can management preserve near term? Is there any opportunity to defer or delay any new vessel deliveries? Can ZIM pay divi if net income is negative?

FY25 FCF and beyond. What is the level of FCF generation expected at the mid- point of the EBITDA guidance? How much debt service (capex + lease + debt repayment, including interest) is expected in FY25? What is the flex around lease and capex spent in FY25 and FY26? What would be the FCF at the low end of the EBIT/EBITDA range? Does the company expect negative FCF in 2026 and 2027?

Sustainability efforts. Has the fleet renewal programme proven to be effective thus far in progressing on ZIM's ESG strategy? Does ZIM expect to be able to charge customers a premium fee for more sustainable transportation products? Will environmental requirements reduce effective capacity? If so, how will the competitive landscape adjust in response, and how fast does ZIM believe this could happen? Recent IMO ambition changed to achieve net zero by 2050, which is in line with ZIM's strategy. What is ZIM's view on what is needed to successfully decarbonise shipping and is the introduction of a market- based mechanism essential to achieve this? What is the expected cost of the entry of shipping into the EU emissions trading scheme for ZIM?
2Q25 preview: volumes ok, rates/yields down QoQ. 2H macro risk remains, published 27 June 2025.
Global Container Shipping: Environmental regulation not costly enough to offset oversupply - confirm UW ratings, published 21 Jan 2025.

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.
Below is the list of companies that constitute the "industry coverage universe":

On 27-Aug-2022, prior to any intra-day change that may have been published, the rating for this security was Underweight, and the adjusted price target was 18671.36.
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

**Valuation Methodology:** Our valuation is based on the relationship between EV/IC and ROIC. We apply 0.4x 2025e invested capital for the group to reflect our view that returns will rebase well below the cost of capital over the next three years as the market moves to oversupply against a weakening demand backdrop post the strong pandemic trading. We then add other assets and deduct net debt and minorities to arrive at our price target.

**Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target:** AP Moller Maersk is principally involved in the world trade market. The main upside risks are that the integrated container shipping strategy delivers value, with better supply management and global supply chain complexity continues to absorb effective capacity. A prolonged trade downturn would leave the risks to our forecasts and valuation to the downside.

Valuation Methodology: We value Hapag- Lloyd based on the relationship between ROIC and EV/IC. Our price target of €93 is based on a 0.92x multiple applied to our Invested Capital estimate in 2025 as we anticipate negative EBIT in 2026, with negative ROIC vs a cost of capital of c7%.

Risks which May impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: More effective capacity management measures improving the supply- demand imbalance. Successful execution of Hapag- Lloyd's terminal and infrastructure acquisitions. Lower unit cost through successful cost reduction programs. Lower bunker fuel costs. Active or passive impact of industry consolidation.
Stock Rating: UNDERWEIGHT
Industry View: NEUTRAL

On 27-Aug-2022, prior to any intra-day change that may have been published, the rating for this security was Equal Weight, and the adjusted price target was 63.00.
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

**Valuation** **Methodology:** We value ZIM on a 0.7x EV/IC applied to our average 2025E/26e IC to reflect our view of significant oversupply risk in 2025 and 2026 assuming the Red Sea disruption eases.

**Risks** **which** **May** **Impede** **the** **Achievement** **of** **the** **Barclays** **Research** **Valuation** **and** **Price** **Target:** ZIM has high operating leverage ($100 on rates impacts 2024E EBITDA by $360mn, all else equal). Stronger than expected global economic growth and hence trade volume growth, stronger than expected freight rates due to capacity-demand balance and bunker oil price movements that are recovered through freight rates are upside risks to our price target. Downside risks include ZIM's expansion strategy potentially diluting earnings, the new vessel leasing plan potentially increasing operational and financial leverage, systems failure leading to increased costs and/or indeed a geopolitical event disrupting operations.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.
